resources.string: * Check out the Library of Radicals
Welcome to this interactive instructional of reading Chinese! Thank you for joining me.
This is intended for people that are currently or have previously studied written Chinese. Please consider looking over the radical library and games afterwards.
In 1916 Ferdinand de Saussure, a Swiss linguist, said
“Time changes all things; there is no reason why language should escape this universal law.”

Any introduction to Chinese characters or Hanzi, will explain that the first were pictographs. As time went on, life changed for the people speaking and writing this language. Their ideas and writing changed. Some things that used to make sense written down, no longer do and as Chinese language learners, we need to accept this.

But fear not! Hanzi can actually be very easy for visual learners if you learn to imagine the parts. These parts are known as radicals. If you can learn to break down “complicated” words in any other language, Chinese is no different.
The woman whose name sounds like “horse” (ma) is the mother (ma).
Not all words are this simple, but enough are that getting comfortable with beginning Chinese can set up your foundation for intermediate level.
Please look up the radical library with 85 different introductory radicals to get you started. Once you’re comfortable there, try some games to see if you’ve gotten the hang of it.
Note: we’re going to focus on radicals- hence the app name. I will be supplying you with tips and tricks to learn them and I hope you find them as useful as I did.
Match the characters below to this radical
This game works best in portrait mode.
Please set your preferred difficulty level to adjust how much time you would like.
The radical at the top indicates what you should be looking for.
There will be six Hanzi with the expected radical, and three without.
Hot tip! Depending on the radical, it may have variants. Double check for those.
This game works best in landscape mode.
Please set your preferred difficulty level to adjust how much time you would like.
Plan an efficient road trip by making the map stops connect together via radicals.
The Start and Stop landmarks should give you a hint to what radical should come next.
There will be six Hanzi with differing radicals that can be selected from drop down menus. If you select one Hanzi, it will be removed from other pit stops.
If you plan successfully, your car will reach its destination. Else, you run out of gas.
This game works best in landscape mode.
Please set your preferred difficulty level to adjust how much time you would like.
On the left, there is a large blank space, that is your canvas
On the right, radicals that may be used as puzzle pieces.
Place the radical in its correct position and it will disappear.
Hot tip! Some radicals will change shape. Also, if there are copies of a radical, it may remove the copy, but that is fine.
